Original Paragraph:
He touched the pencil-line scar behind his ear where the cylinder was
buried, marveling at the power stored there, power to fling him from
earth to this fourth planet of the Centaurian system in an instant.
It had happened so fast that he could almost feel the warm, humid
Missouri air, though he was light years from Missouri.

Original Paragraph:
He got up. A gray, funnel-shaped cloud of dust stood off to his left.
This became disturbing, since there was scarcely enough wind to move
his hair. He watched it, trying to recall what he might know about
cyclones. But he knew little. Weather control made cyclones and other
climatic phenomena on earth practically non-existent. The cloud
did not move, though, except to spin on its axis rapidly, emitting
a high-pitched, scarcely audible whine, like a high speed motor. He
judged it harmless.
Prompt:
Character: A man, standing in a desolate landscape. He recalls his limited knowledge of weather anomalies.
Setting: Gray dust cloud looms to his left, spinning rapidly without wind.
Action: The stationary cyclone emits a high-pitched whine. Man assesses its harmlessness.
Tone: Matter-of-fact and observant
Descriptive Details: Observe man's actions and emotions; Expand on the unsettling nature of the still cyclonic cloud in the context of a windless environment.
Incorporate Sci-fi Elements: Recall how weather control technology has made cyclones rare occurrences.
Create Vivid Picture: Utilize sensory details to emphasize the man's unease and the eerie nature of the stationary cyclone.

Original Paragraph:

Original Paragraph:
He turned his back and walked away. When he looked up the wind devil

Emphasize the mature tone, incorporating dark humor and cerebral themes, and blend rich description with vivid sensory details.
